AvProblem.comment: possible at any time of day or night

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh snowdrifts at hight altitudes, glide-snow avalanches in steep terrain
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanche danger is moderate in general, at high altitudes in extended east-facing terrain behind discontinuities there are snowdrift accumulations which in places can be triggered by 1 person, releases reaching medium-to-large size. On steep slopes in all aspects, naturally triggered glide-snow and wet-snow avalanches can be expected. Glide cracks are indicators of immiment danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: At high altitudes the fresh snow (up to 15 cm) plus brisk W/NW winds will generate fresh snowdrift accumulations, often poorly bonded with the snowpack surface. Otherwise the snowpack surface above 2000 m is often hard and icy. At intermediate and lower altitudes the snowpack is very moist-to-wet due to rain impact, can glide over smooth ground. The slopes at intermediate and lower altitudes are becoming bare of snow.
BulletinMeasurements.wxSynopsisComment: Sunday will bring gray skies to Styria, the peaks often veiled in fog. Rainfall/snowfall is expected, possibly heavy in the morning, snowfall level dropping from 1800 down to 1300 m in the north and 1500 m in the south during the course of the day. In afternoon, precipitation will slacken off. At 2000 m: in the north and west from +2 to -4 degrees; in the south and east from 0 to -3 degrees. Brisk W/NW winds.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In the Northern Alps a few snow showers will pass through on Monday, thereafter clouds will disperse. Dry in southern regions. The snowdrift problem will recede, gliding snow activity will persist.

AvProblem.comment: small, thin snowdrifts at high altitudes

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Some fresh snowdrifts at high altitudes, isolated glide-snow/wet-snow avalanches in steep terrain
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanche danger is generally low. At high altitudes in extended east facing terrain, small snowdrift accumulations which in places can be triggered by 1 person, releases reaching medium-to-large size. On steep slopes in all aspects, naturally triggered glide-snow and wet-snow avalanches can be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: At high altitudes the fresh snow plus brisk W/NW winds will generate fresh snowdrift accumulations, often poorly bonded with the snowpack surface. Otherwise the snowpack surface above 2000 m is often hard and icy. At intermediate and lower altitudes the snowpack is very moist-to-wet due to rain impact, can glide over smooth ground. The slopes at intermediate and lower altitudes are becoming bare of snow.
BulletinMeasurements.wxSynopsisComment: Sunday will bring gray skies to Styria, the peaks often veiled in fog. Rainfall/snowfall is expected, possibly heavy in the morning, snowfall level dropping from 1800 down to 1300 m in the north and 1500 m in the south during the course of the day. In afternoon, precipitation will slacken off. At 2000 m: in the north and west from +2 to -4 degrees; in the south and east from 0 to -3 degrees. Brisk W/NW winds.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: On Monday, improved weather conditions, slightly cooler. Avalanche danger will remain low.
